markdownRemark.html:
I am going to explain in as simple terms as possible why we should implement a Universal Basic Income (UBI)

First let’s define UBI to ensure we’re all on the same page. Andrew Yang proposes giving every adult citizen in the U.S. $1,000/month, so for simplicity’s sake that will be the UBI.

There are two primary angles to looking at it, from a practical and moral perspective.

Moral

The moral perspective is obvious - the idea is that nobody in a wealthy country should be neglected of basic humanitarian needs. This is why we have social programs that target those who need help (welfare, food stamps, disability benefits, medicaid).

This extends not just to a lack of goods/services essential to survival (food, emergency healthcare), but to things deemed useful - such as primary and secondary K-12 education.

Nobody needs K-12 education to survive. But at some point we decided that every kid should have access to a high school education regardless of the financial situation of their family.

Given that we already provide these anti-poverty measures, replacing these often convoluted means-testing measures with a simple check doesn’t go against any values we already have, an in fact seems more efficient.

Now the first objection that many will raise at this point is regarding moral hazard - “won’t people just stop working?”

frontmatter.title: Why We Should Implement a Universal Basic Income
